title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act titled "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997" is also known as the "Short Title". It includes findings outlined in Section 2. The Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997 acknowledges the rapid growth of private security officers in the US, their role in crime prevention, and the opportunities they provide for job seekers. These officers protect various entities such as banks, hospitals, airports, and schools. Private security officers play a significant role in protecting various entities such as hospitals, chemical companies, airports, and schools. They supplement sworn law enforcement officers and are more likely to be encountered by the public due to the growth of private shopping malls. The growth of private security services has outpaced the number of public sector law enforcement officers, leading to increased contact with private security personnel. Despite differences in duties, the public struggles to differentiate between private security and sworn law enforcement officers. The demand for qualified and well-trained private security personnel is high. The American public demands well-trained private security personnel as an adjunct to, not a replacement for, sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers should undergo thorough screening, especially since many carry weapons. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Employers of private security officers can request an association designated by the Attorney General to submit fingerprints for background checks. Employees can give authorization for this process. The Attorney General will search criminal records and provide results within 30 days. The Attorney General designates associations to submit employee fingerprints for background checks. The associations must provide identification and criminal history records to the requesting employer within one business day. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. An association designated by the Attorney General must transfer identification and criminal history records to employers within one business day. The association also needs to provide copies of this information to licensing authorities and regulatory agencies in the relevant states. The Attorney General can establish regulations for the security, accuracy, and dissemination of this information, including the imposition of necessary fees. Additionally, the Attorney General is required to report to the Senate. The Attorney General must report to Congress on the number of employer inquiries and their outcomes regarding the transfer of identification and criminal history records. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends section 534 of title 28, United States Code to include private security officers' employers for conducting background checks. 

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Imposes a fine or imprisonment for misuse of information obtained under section 3 for private security officer employment purposes.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are not liable for damages. In this Act, key terms are defined including "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." The definition of "employer" includes providing services of private security officers and being licensed or certified by states. The term "fingerprint" in the Act includes any approved method of positive identification by the Attorney General. A "private security officer" is an individual who provides security services for compensation, excluding sworn police officers and licensed professionals. Sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal audit or credit employees, individuals on active military duty, electronic security system company employees, and employees involved in reporting or apprehending shoplifters or trespassers are exempt from being considered private security officers under the Act. The term "security services" refers to activities such as observing and reporting intrusion, theft, vandalism, or unlawful activities, deterring theft, protecting individuals or property, and secure prisoner movement. This definition excludes certain individuals like sworn police officers, military personnel, electronic security system employees, and armored vehicle company employees from being classified as private security officers under the Act. Private security services involve activities such as deterring theft, observing and reporting unlawful activities, protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public events, and providing canine services for detecting unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to various states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. Private security services include deterring theft, observing unlawful activities, protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public events, and providing canine services for detecting unlawful substances. The term "State" encompasses several states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
